CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 35 On the other hand , Li and co-workers employed the difluoro-substituted thiopheneconjugated side chain to construct bi(alkyl-difluorothienyl)benzodithiophene-fluorobenzotriazole copolymer J91 , which was shown to exhibit superior cell performance than that of the Article nonfluorinated control polymer. The PSC based on J91 / m-ITIC as an active layer with thermal annealing gave a high PCE of 11.63% with a high V oc of 0.98 V and a J sc of 18.03 mA cm^-2 . 36 The improved cell performance was attributed to the suppression of carrier recombination imposed by the difluorosubstituted side chain. In addition to influencing molecular and functional properties of donor polymers , the structural modification could lead to severe aggregation , which could hamper solution processability of a polymer. On the other hand , aggregation could be desirable and provide a useful tool to control the bulkheterojunction ( BHJ ) film morphology and then the photovoltaic performance of a solar cell. Yan and co-workers employed the branched alkyl chains attached on the backbone of the difluorobenzothiadiazole-quaterthiophene ( PffBT4T ) copolymer to acquire desirable temperature - dependent aggregation behavior. By spin - casting the polymer solution at an elevated temperature , they could control the morphology and crystallinity of the polymer films. Taking advantage of this aggregation control approach , high - performance PSCs based on PffBT4T-2OD:PC71BM were fabricated affording a PCE of up to 10.8% . 9 Guo and co-workers used a number of fused thiophene spacers to tune the aggregation behavior of difluorobenzoxadiazole (ffBX)-based donor polymers among which PffBX-TT with thieno[3,2-b]thiophene as a spacer showed intermediate temperature - dependent aggregation strength allowing the control of blend film morphology during PSC fabrication. PSCs using PffBX-TT:PC71BM as an active layer gave a maximum PCE of 9.10% . 37 Previously , we developed a class of benzodithiophene - based donor polymers with fluoro-dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole being an acceptor unit that showed interesting temperature - dependent aggregation behavior when equipped with linear alkyl side chains. PSCs based on these polymers : PC71BM blend layers showed good photovoltaic performance with a maximum PCE as high as 9.70% . 38 In this contribution , we reported a new series of donor polymer materials based on benzodithiophene ( BDT ) and difluorinated dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole , PffBB-n ( n = 10 , 12 , 14 , or 16 ) , which exhibited strong aggregation behavior in both solution and thin films. In addition to the size of alkyl side chains attached on the backbone of the polymer , aggregation can be modulated by the solvent used and temperature applied on the film with which the absorption cut - off extended down to ∼ 780 nm in thin films , resulting in a narrow optical band gap of ∼ 1.6 eV. Such wide absorption is desirable and complementary to that of the commonly used PC71BM acceptor material in the visible light region , which can increase light harvesting in BHJ PSCs.

Let's think step by step.

1. bi(alkyl-difluorothienyl)benzodithiophene-fluorobenzotriazole copolymer J91
2. m-ITIC
3. difluorobenzothiadiazole-quaterthiophene (PffBT4T)
4. PC71BM
5. fused thiophene spacers in PffBX-TT
6. benzodithiophene-based donor polymers with fluoro-dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole
7. PffBB-n (n = 10, 12, 14, or 16)

These are the Material Name entities identified in the paragraph.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. bi(alkyl-difluorothienyl)benzodithiophene-fluorobenzotriazole copolymer J91
2. m-ITIC
3. difluorobenzothiadiazole-quaterthiophene (PffBT4T)
4. PC71BM
5. PffBX-TT
6. benzodithiophene-based donor polymers with fluoro-dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole
7. PffBB-n (n = 10, 12, 14, or 16)

These are the Material Name entities that clearly refer to specific materials mentioned in the paragraph.

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

PN.content:
Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 35 On the other hand , Li and co-workers employed the difluoro-substituted thiopheneconjugated side chain to construct bi(alkyl-difluorothienyl)benzodithiophene-fluorobenzotriazole copolymer J91 , which was shown to exhibit superior cell performance than that of the Article nonfluorinated control polymer. The PSC based on J91 / m-ITIC as an active layer with thermal annealing gave a high PCE of 11.63% with a high V oc of 0.98 V and a J sc of 18.03 mA cm^-2 . 36 The improved cell performance was attributed to the suppression of carrier recombination imposed by the difluorosubstituted side chain. In addition to influencing molecular and functional properties of donor polymers , the structural modification could lead to severe aggregation , which could hamper solution processability of a polymer. On the other hand , aggregation could be desirable and provide a useful tool to control the bulkheterojunction ( BHJ ) film morphology and then the photovoltaic performance of a solar cell. Yan and co-workers employed the branched alkyl chains attached on the backbone of the difluorobenzothiadiazole-quaterthiophene ( PffBT4T ) copolymer to acquire desirable temperature - dependent aggregation behavior. By spin - casting the polymer solution at an elevated temperature , they could control the morphology and crystallinity of the polymer films. Taking advantage of this aggregation control approach , high - performance PSCs based on PffBT4T-2OD:PC71BM were fabricated affording a PCE of up to 10.8% . 9 Guo and co-workers used a number of fused thiophene spacers to tune the aggregation behavior of difluorobenzoxadiazole (ffBX)-based donor polymers among which PffBX-TT with thieno[3,2-b]thiophene as a spacer showed intermediate temperature - dependent aggregation strength allowing the control of blend film morphology during PSC fabrication. PSCs using PffBX-TT:PC71BM as an active layer gave a maximum PCE of 9.10% . 37 Previously , we developed a class of benzodithiophene - based donor polymers with fluoro-dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole being an acceptor unit that showed interesting temperature - dependent aggregation behavior when equipped with linear alkyl side chains. PSCs based on these polymers : PC71BM blend layers showed good photovoltaic performance with a maximum PCE as high as 9.70% . 38 In this contribution , we reported a new series of donor polymer materials based on benzodithiophene ( BDT ) and difluorinated dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole , PffBB-n ( n = 10 , 12 , 14 , or 16 ) , which exhibited strong aggregation behavior in both solution and thin films. In addition to the size of alkyl side chains attached on the backbone of the polymer , aggregation can be modulated by the solvent used and temperature applied on the film with which the absorption cut - off extended down to ∼ 780 nm in thin films , resulting in a narrow optical band gap of ∼ 1.6 eV. Such wide absorption is desirable and complementary to that of the commonly used PC71BM acceptor material in the visible light region , which can increase light harvesting in BHJ PSCs.

Let's think step by step.

1. J91: bi(alkyl-difluorothienyl)benzodithiophene-fluorobenzotriazole copolymer
2. m-ITIC: unspecified material, likely an acceptor material
3. PSC: Polymer Solar Cell
4. PCE: Power Conversion Efficiency
5. Voc: Voltage at Open Circuit
6. Jsc: Short Circuit Current Density
7. PffBT4T: difluorobenzothiadiazole-quaterthiophene copolymer
8. PffBT4T-2OD: branched alkyl chains modified version of PffBT4T
9. PC71BM: unspecified material, likely an acceptor material
10. PffBX: difluorobenzoxadiazole
11. ffBX-TT: fused thieno[3,2-b]thiophene modified version of ffBX
12. BDT: Benzodithiophene
13. PffBB-n: series of donor polymers based on benzodithiophene and difluorinated dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole, with n representing the size of alkyl side chains.
14. PC: unspecified material, likely an acceptor material in the context of the previous paragraph, but not explicitly stated in this paragraph.
15. BHJ: Bulk Heterojunction
16. Absorption cut-off: The wavelength beyond which a material does not absorb light.
17. Optical band gap: The energy required to move an electron from the valence band to the conduction band in a material.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

1. J91: copolymer
2. m-ITIC: unspecified material
3. PCE: Power Conversion Efficiency
4. Voc: Voltage at Open Circuit
5. Jsc: Short Circuit Current Density
6. PffBT4T: copolymer
7. PC71BM: unspecified material
8. PffBX: difluorobenzoxadiazole
9. ffBX-TT: modified version of PffBX
10. BDT: Benzodithiophene
11. PffBB-n: series of donor polymers based on benzodithiophene and difluorinated dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole
12. Absorption cut-off: wavelength
13. Optical band gap: energy.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Name |
| --- |
| Power Conversion Efficiency (PCE) |
| Voltage at Open Circuit (Voc) |
| Short Circuit Current Density (Jsc) |
| copolymer J91 |
| unspecified material m-ITIC |
| copolymer PffBT4T |
| unspecified material PC71BM |
| difluorobenzoxadiazole PffBX |
| modified version of PffBX, ffBX-TT |
| Benzodithiophene BDT |
| series of donor polymers PffBB-n |
| wavelength Absorption cut-off |
| energy Optical band gap |

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 35 On the other hand , Li and co-workers employed the difluoro-substituted thiopheneconjugated side chain to construct bi(alkyl-difluorothienyl)benzodithiophene-fluorobenzotriazole copolymer J91 , which was shown to exhibit superior cell performance than that of the Article nonfluorinated control polymer. The PSC based on J91 / m-ITIC as an active layer with thermal annealing gave a high PCE of 11.63% with a high V oc of 0.98 V and a J sc of 18.03 mA cm^-2 . 36 The improved cell performance was attributed to the suppression of carrier recombination imposed by the difluorosubstituted side chain. In addition to influencing molecular and functional properties of donor polymers , the structural modification could lead to severe aggregation , which could hamper solution processability of a polymer. On the other hand , aggregation could be desirable and provide a useful tool to control the bulkheterojunction ( BHJ ) film morphology and then the photovoltaic performance of a solar cell. Yan and co-workers employed the branched alkyl chains attached on the backbone of the difluorobenzothiadiazole-quaterthiophene ( PffBT4T ) copolymer to acquire desirable temperature - dependent aggregation behavior. By spin - casting the polymer solution at an elevated temperature , they could control the morphology and crystallinity of the polymer films. Taking advantage of this aggregation control approach , high - performance PSCs based on PffBT4T-2OD:PC71BM were fabricated affording a PCE of up to 10.8% . 9 Guo and co-workers used a number of fused thiophene spacers to tune the aggregation behavior of difluorobenzoxadiazole (ffBX)-based donor polymers among which PffBX-TT with thieno[3,2-b]thiophene as a spacer showed intermediate temperature - dependent aggregation strength allowing the control of blend film morphology during PSC fabrication. PSCs using PffBX-TT:PC71BM as an active layer gave a maximum PCE of 9.10% . 37 Previously , we developed a class of benzodithiophene - based donor polymers with fluoro-dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole being an acceptor unit that showed interesting temperature - dependent aggregation behavior when equipped with linear alkyl side chains. PSCs based on these polymers : PC71BM blend layers showed good photovoltaic performance with a maximum PCE as high as 9.70% . 38 In this contribution , we reported a new series of donor polymer materials based on benzodithiophene ( BDT ) and difluorinated dialkylthienylbenzothiadiazole , PffBB-n ( n = 10 , 12 , 14 , or 16 ) , which exhibited strong aggregation behavior in both solution and thin films. In addition to the size of alkyl side chains attached on the backbone of the polymer , aggregation can be modulated by the solvent used and temperature applied on the film with which the absorption cut - off extended down to ∼ 780 nm in thin films , resulting in a narrow optical band gap of ∼ 1.6 eV. Such wide absorption is desirable and complementary to that of the commonly used PC71BM acceptor material in the visible light region , which can increase light harvesting in BHJ PSCs.

Let's think step by step.

1. J91 copolymer: PCE = 11.63%, Voc = 0.98 V, Jsc = 18.03 mA cm^-2
2. PffBT4T copolymer: PCE = 10.8%
3. PffBX-TT polymer: PCE = 9.10%
4. Benzodithiophene-based donor polymers: PCE = maximum 9.70%
5. PffBB-n polymers: exhibited strong aggregation behavior, absorption cut-off ∼ 780 nm in thin films, optical band gap ∼ 1.6 eV.

These values are all in terms of percentage (%) for the photovoltaic cell efficiency (PCE), and volts (V) and amperes (A) for the open circuit voltage (Voc) and short circuit current density (Jsc), respectively. The units for the current densities are typically in mA cm^-2. The alkyl side chains in the polymers are not explicitly stated with their number of carbon atoms, so no specific values can be identified for them.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

1. J91 copolymer: PCE = 11.63%
2. PffBT4T copolymer: PCE = 10.8%
3. PffBX-TT polymer: PCE = 9.10%
4. Benzodithiophene-based donor polymers: PCE = maximum 9.70%
5. PffBB-n polymers: optical band gap ∼ 1.6 eV.

These values are all in terms of percentage (%) for the photovoltaic cell efficiency (PCE), and eV for the optical band gap.
